questions.text: Given below is a postpartum hysterectomy specimen showing placental insertion. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows placenta percreta as the placenta extends to the serosal edge. There is no myometrium at this site.

Accrete syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive or adhered placenta. This is due to:

  • Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis 
  • Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.  

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta

(most common)  

Villi are attached to the myometrium

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus?
questions.solution:
Serotypes 16 and 18 are present in the bivalent vaccine against the human papillomavirus (HPV). It is called Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.

Gardasil/Silgard is the quadrivalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16 and 18 and is given at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Gardasil 9 is the nonavalent vaccine against HPV. It has serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. In 2020 it has received an expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers.

questions.text: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. How much progesterone is released by this device?
questions.solution:
Progestasert releases 65 μg of progesterone/day.

Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of IUCDs.

There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly replacement.

questions.text: An obese woman with dysmenorrhea and irregular periods is diagnosed with dystocia dystrophia syndrome. What type of pelvis is seen here?
questions.solution:
In dystocia dystrophia syndrome, an android pelvis is seen.

Dystocia dystrophia syndrome:

  • The patient is stockily built with a bull neck, broad shoulders, and short thighs. She is obese with a male distribution of hair.
  • Subfertile, with dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or irregular periods.
  • There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity.
  • The pelvis is of the android type. The occipito-posterior position is common.
  • During labor, there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia, leading to difficult instrumental delivery or cesarean section.
  • There is a chance of lactation failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of placental separation in stage 3 of parturition of a pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation.

Signs of placental separation:

  • The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear)
  • Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it
  • Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
  • Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no longer recedes
  • A sudden gush of blood
  • Permanent lengthening of cord

Note: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterine action.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man underwent semen analysis as a part of an infertility workup. The results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Sperm concentration - 16 million/ml
  • pH - 7.5
  • Volume - 2 mL
  • Agglutination is absent
  • Morphology - 60% normal and 60% motile sperms
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia.

Different types of disorders of sperms are as follows:

  • Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.
  • Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.
  • Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.
  • Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.
  • Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.
  • Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.

Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: The most common symptom of Adenomyosis is ______
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of Adenomyosis is Menorrhagia.

Adenomyosis

  • This is characterized by uterine enlargement caused by ectopic rests of endometrium—both glands and stroma— located deep within the myometrium.
    • When these rests are scattered throughout the myometrium - diffuse adenomyosis
    • When the rests form a localized nodular collection - focal adenomyosis
  • Symptoms of adenomyosis typically include menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain where menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea are more common.
     
  • Transvaginal sonography and MR imaging are the preferred methods of diagnosis.
  • Hysterectomy is the definitive mode of treatment.

questions.text: An anxious mother pregnant with twins was recently diagnosed with twin-twin transfusion syndrome. She wants to know the possible fetal outcome of the pregnancy. Which of the following investigations can be used to predict this?
questions.solution:
In twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), the fetal outcome depends on the cardiac function of the recipient twin. Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is used to assess the ventricular function using doppler.

Option A: Deepest vertical pocket on USG is used to diagnose polyhydramnios-oligohydramnios in TTTS.

Options B and D: Fetal haemoglobin and MCA peak systolic velocity are used to diagnose TAPS (Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome).

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup. Her BP is 152/96mmHg. Urine analysis shows proteinuria of 3+. All of the following would be consistent with her probable diagnosis, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pre-eclampsia and low fibronectin is not a feature of pre-eclampsia.

Features associated with pre-eclampsia:

  • Fibronectin is a glycoprotein associated with vascular endothelial cell basement membrane and is elevated in women with preeclampsia.
  • Thrombocytopenia (HELLP syndrome)
  • Hemolysis (HELLP syndrome)
  • Increased hemoglobin, caused by a decrease in plasma volume.

Hemoconcentration is a hallmark of eclampsia. In preeclampsia, hemoconcentration is present but usually not marked.

questions.text: A Pap smear from a patient is shown below. Identify the characteristics of the cell seen.
questions.solution:
The cell shown above from a pap smear is an intermediate squamous cell, which is progesterone-dominant. Cells seen in pap smear are:

Type of cell Identification features
Basal & Parabasal cells

Cells are small, rounded, basophilic, with large nuclei. 

Predominantly seen in smears from post-menopausal women
 Intermediate cells

Cells are squamous cells, transparent and basophilic (blue/green) with vesicular nuclei.

Progesterone-dominant
Superficial cells 

Cells are acidophilic (pink), with pyknotic nuclei

Estrogen-dominant
Malignant cells Hyperchromatic nuclei, granular chromatin and scanty cytoplasm in undifferentiated malignant cells.
Human papillomavirus-infected cells Koilocytes with perinuclear halo and peripheral condensation of cytoplasm

A predominance of superficial or superficial and intermediate cells is seen in women of reproductive age. A predominance of intermediate cells is seen in the luteal phase, in pregnancy, with amenorrhea, and in newborns, premenarchal girls, and women in early menopausal transition. A predominance of parabasal cells is seen in menopausal patients with atrophy.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: What is the most common site of vulval cancers?
questions.solution: The most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora.

questions.text: Which bone is commonly perforated during decapitation in an aftercoming head in breech?
questions.solution:
Occipital bone is commonly perforated during decapitation in an after coming head in breech.

The perforation site of the presenting part during decapitation are:

Presenting part Perforation site
Vertex Parietal bone
Brow Frontal bone
Face Orbit/Roof of mouth
After coming head in breech Occiput

questions.text: Given below is the partograph of a primigravida in labor. What should be the next step in managing her condition?

choices.text: Induction of labor by mechanical methods

questions.solution:
As the plotting on the above partograph has crossed the action line, the next step of management is Caesarean section.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: What is the capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH?
questions.solution:
The capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH is 300 to 500 mL.

Bakri balloon is used in uterine tamponade in cases of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management.

Insertion of Bakri balloon requires three team members.

  • One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. 
  • Another member places the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilizes it. 
  • The third member instills fluid to inflate the balloon.

Initially, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL of normal saline is done. It is followed by further infusion over a few minutes up to 300 to 500 mL.

questions.text: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. Identify structure A.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta.

Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types:

  • Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum form the placenta. 
  • Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. 
  • Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus.

The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve.

As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'.

Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

questions.text: In gestational diabetes, which of the following is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia?
questions.solution:
BMI (body mass index) is an independent and substantial risk factor for macrosomia in both diabetic and non-diabetic mothers.

BMI levels are associated with increased birth weight, regardless of glucose levels. Gestational diabetes prevalence increases by approximately 1 percent for every 1 kg/m2 increase in BMI.

BMI cutoffs for pregnancy:

Underweight - < 18 kg/m2 

Normal - 18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2 

Overweight - 25 to 29.9 kg/m2 

Obese - >30 kg/m2 

Weight distribution also seems to play a role because the risk of gestational diabetes is increased with truncal obesity. HbA1c levels are associated with fetal malformations in pre-gestational diabetes.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the ANC clinic for the first time at 14 weeks of gestation. She complains of excessive nausea and vomiting. On examination, fundal height is midway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus. The T sign in seen on USG. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the T sign seen on USG points towards a diagnosis of monochorionic diamniotic twins.

The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the separating membrane is made up only by the two amniotic membranes with no intervening chorion. This can be seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning of the second trimester.

Symptoms of multifetal pregnancy:

  • Increased nausea and vomiting in early months
  • Palpitations and shortness of breath
  • Increased swelling of legs, varicose veins and haemorrhoids
  • Unusual rate of uterine growth
  • Excessive fetal movements

Signs of multifetal pregnancy:

  • Increased weight gain
  • Hypertension
  • Barrel shaped abdomen
  • Increased fundal height and abdominal girth
  • Multiple fetal parts
  • Palpation of 2 fetal heads 
  • FHS at different spots with FHR difference of at least 10bpm

Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy is terminated between 34-37 weeks+6 days.

The below image shows the T sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.solution:
As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine atony as a part of the management of PPH.

AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics are the most important components in AMTSL to do so.

The currently recommended components of AMTSL are as follows:

1. Injecting uterotonics within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after delivery of the anterior shoulder
  • Most important step
  • Oxytocin 10 IU im/iv infusion is the preferred uterotonic.

(Not recommended by WHO- carboprost)

 
2 Delayed cord clamping
  • Done within 1-3 mins of delivery
  • 80 ml of additional blood goes to the fetus
  • Prevents fetal anemia
3 Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrews technique
  • The uterus is pushed upwards and backward
  • The traction of cord is downwards and forwards
4 Intermittent assessment of uterine tone Done every 15 mins for 2 hours

Note: In the event that uterine atony is diagnosed during the assessment of uterine tone, uterine massage can be performed to control PPH.

questions.text: Staging laparotomy was performed in a teenage girl who presented with an adnexal mass. Histopathological examination showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor).

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin.

The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. What is the reflex elicited in the process?
questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex.

Fetal ejection reflex or Ferguson reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has been suggested but not proven.

It is seen in stripping/sweeping and artificial rupture of membranes. Both of these are methods of induction of labor. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost/carboprost.

questions.text: You are assisting a case of vaginal hysterectomy where your assistant professor asks you to hold the retractor shown in the image. What is this retractor known as?
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a Simon vaginal retractor, used to retract vaginal walls during examination and vaginal procedures.

The below image is of Doyen's retractor. It is used during abdominal procedures like C-section.

questions.text: A patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy is planned for medical management with methotrexate. What is the multi-dose protocol for this drug?
questions.solution:
In the multi-dose protocol, methotrexate is given at a dose of 1 mg/kg as an IM injection on alternate days 1, 3, 5, and 7.

This regimen is continued on alternating days until the hCG level drops by 15% over two days. Up to 4 doses may be given. Along with this, leucovorin rescue (folinic acid) is given at 0.1 mg/kg after 24 hrs (on days 2, 4, 6, and 8) to buffer the side effects of methotrexate.

MTX Protocol Multi-dose regimen Single-dose regimen
Dose 

1 mg/kg
(+ 0.1 mg/kg LEU)

50 mg/m2
(Body surface area)
Regimen Alternate daily doses  Day 0
hCG measurement Days 0, 1, 3, 5, 7 Days 0, 4, 7
Treatment success hCG declines >15% from the previous value hCG declines >15% between Day 4 and 7
When to administer additional dose   2nd, 3rd or 4th dose to be given if hCG does not decline 15% from the previous value. Maximum 4 doses   Second dose on Day 7 if hCG does not decline 15% 

 Note: If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about human chorionic gonadotropin?

choices.text: Alpha subunit is identical to LH, FSH, TSH
It causes involution of corpus luteum
Maximum level is seen at 60-70 days of gestation
Detected in serum 8-9 days after fertilisation

questions.solution:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) does not cause involution of the corpus luteum, but it maintains corpus luteum function.

hCG is produced by the syncitiotrophoblasts of the placenta. It is a glycoprotein hormone with two subunits. The alpha-subunit is similar to LH, FSH and TSH. The beta-subunit is specific and is measured by pregnancy tests.

hCG can be detected in maternal blood 8 days after fertilisation. Thus, it can help in diagnosis of pregnancy even before the period is missed. Its levels nearly doubles every 48 hours in early pregnancy reaching a maximum of 50000 - 100000 IU/L by 60-70 days of gestation. Then the level starts falling reaching a minimum at 16 weeks, which continues throughout pregnancy.

The various placental hormones and their functions are given below. 

Placental hormones Functions 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

Structurally similar to - LH, FSH, TSH
  • Maintains corpus luteum function
  • Regulates testosterone secretion from fetal testes
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid

Placental lactogen (PL)

Structurally similar to - GH, Prolactin
  • Helps the mother adapt to fetal energy requirements

Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
  • Vascular and myometrial smooth muscle relaxation
  • Initiation of parturition
  • Stimulates placental ACTH production 

Placental adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) 

 Stimulates fetal and maternal adrenal glucocorticoid production

Other placental hormones include:

  • GnRH, TRH, GHRH, Growth hormone variant (hGH-V)
  • Parathyroid hormone-releasing protein (PTH-rP)
  • Inhibin 
  • Activin
  • Relaxin

questions.text:
Which of the following coagulation factors are increased in pregnancy?
  1. II
  2. VII
  3. IX
  4. XI
  5. XIII
questions.solution:
All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factors XI and XIII.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state with physiological changes such as:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factors XI and XIII)
  • Fibrinogen levels are also increased
  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to hemodilution
  • Clotting time and bleeding time is unaffected

The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and the women are generally asymptomatic.

Related Pearl: Hematological changes in pregnancy

Increases

Decreases

Hemoglobin mass

Hemoglobin concentration

Total plasma protein

S.urea/creatinine/uric acid

Globulin

Albumin

Neutrophils

Platelets

Fibrinogen

Blood urea nitrogen

Factors 7,8,9,10

Factor 11,13

Insulin

S.Na/K/Ca/Mg/I2

LDL,HDL,apolipoprotiens

-

S.Transferrin and TIBC(Total

Iron binding capcity)

S.Iron, ferritin

CRP(C-Reactive protein)

  

Placental phosphatase

  

Total alkaline phosphatase

  

ESR 4x rise

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding sonography in pregnancy?

choices.text: All machines must display thermal index
Tissue heating is higher with shorter examination time
Risks are greater during organogenesis than later in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Tissue heating is higher with longer examination time.

Sonography should be performed in compliance with the ALARA principle which is As Low As Reasonably Achievable. The theoretical risks are greater during organogenesis (8-15 weeks) than later in pregnancy. 

All sonography machines must display 2 indices - the thermal index and the mechanical index.

questions.text: Which of the following agents has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Prolactin has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy.

Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes.

The etiology of peripartum cardiomyopathy remains unknown. Many potential causes have been proposed but are not proven.

  • Viral myocarditis
  • Abnormal immune response to pregnancy
  • Abnormal response to the increased hemodynamic burden of pregnancy
  • Malnutrition
  • Inflammation
  • Apoptosis
  • Prolactin

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation.

Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion ≥5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible.

Hysterectomy types include:

  • Type I - Simple / extrafascial
  • Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim
  • Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim
  • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy
  • Type V - Exenteration.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are lost. This causes urethrocele.

DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: A 58-year-old, postmenopausal woman presented with bleeding PV. Hysteroscopic biopsy revealed complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the risk of progression of this condition to cancer?
questions.solution:
Complex hyperplasia with atypia has a 29% increased risk of progression to endometrial cancer. It has the highest risk of progressing to carcinoma compared to other varieties of endometrial hyperplasia.

The risk of endometrial hyperplasia progressing to cancer is tabulated below.

Type of hyperplasia Progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

questions.text: A G3A3 patient was admitted to the hospital with catastrophic APLS following a spontaneous abortion. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a rapidly progressive thromboembolic disorder
At least 2 organ systems should be involved to make a diagnosis
Infections can act as a trigger
IVIG can be used for treatment

questions.solution:
Catastrophic antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (CAPS) is a complication of APLA syndrome, in which ≥3 organ systems are involved. It is also known as Asherson syndrome.

It is seen in both primary and secondary APLA syndrome. Triggering factors include infections, trauma, and obstetric causes. IVIG can be used in CAPS when the first-line therapies with aspirin and heparin have failed.

Note: Asherman syndrome is an acquired condition characterised by formation of intrauterine adhesions or synechiae.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopic examination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and gram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling keloids.

The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear along the lymphatic drainage channels.

The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of the hypervascular intravaginal tissues. 

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: Colour doppler studies in a patient with velamentous cord insertion revealed fetal vessels which were overlying the cervical os. Which of the following is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: Bleeding is triggered by membrane rupture
Bleeding is managed by category I caesarian section

questions.solution:
The doppler findings are suggestive of vasa previa. Maternal mortality is not seen in vasa previa, but fetal mortality is seen.

Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture.

Fetal mortality is high and is due to fetal exsanguination.

Investigations of vasa previa:

  • Colour flow Doppler (TVS)
  • Singer's alkali denaturation test - to detect nucleated red blood cells
  • Apt test (alkali denaturation test) - to detect fetal haemoglobin

Management of vasa previa:

  • No bleeding
    • 28-32 weeks - antenatal corticosteroids
    • 30-34 weeks - admission for surveillance
    • ≥37 weeks - elective caesarean section
  • Bleeding present
    • Category I emergency caesarean section is done (immediate threat to the life of mother or fetus and decision delivery interval <30 mins)

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography was done in a young woman with infertility and menstrual abnormalities. Which of the following findings would not point towards a diagnosis of tubercular salpingitis?

choices.text: A wedge shaped defect at the uterine isthmus
Beading and variations in filling defect
Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline

questions.solution:
A wedge-shaped defect is not suggestive of tubercular salpingitis. It is seen at the uterine isthmus in patients with a history of Cesarean section with a uterine scar.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) features of genital tuberculosis are:

  • Lead pipe appearance due to rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube 
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like outpouching surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes. 

The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. The tubercle bacilli are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium. They come to the surface just before menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation.

Menstrual blood can also be used for detecting mycobacteria.

An HSG showing the features of tuberculous salpingitis is given below.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium.

Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected.

Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text: Chorionic villus sampling was performed on a G2P1 Rh-negative woman at 10 weeks of gestation. What is the dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin that should be administered?
questions.solution:
The dose of Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given in the first trimester is 50 μg.

All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 μg of Rh-immune globulin IM in the first trimester in the following conditions:

  • Within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion
  • Ectopic/molar pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling 

Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should receive a full dose of 300 μg. Generally, a 300 μg dose will protect a woman from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood. 

The dose in the 3rd trimester and post-delivery is 300 μg or 1500 international units (IU).

questions.text: Considering the following image, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Hysteroscopy is the preferred modality for making the diagnosis
HSG (hysterosalpingography) cannot differentiate between the bicornuate and septate uteri

questions.solution:
The given image shows HSG(hysterosalpingography). It can either be a bicornuate uterus or a septate uterus.

HSG provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour, so it cannot distinguish between septate and bicornuate uteri.

Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours and can differentiate septate from bicornuate uteri.

Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and differentiation between the septate uterus and bicornuate uterus.

3D TV US is recommended as the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected septate or bicornuate uterus, especially before planning surgery.

MRI should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TVS is not possible like virgins.

Hysteroscopy cannot reliably differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate uterus unless a laparoscopy to view the uterine fundus is also performed.

 

In the images given below: A-Normal, B-Unicornuate, C-Arcuate, D to G-Septate uterus of different grades, H-Bicornuate, I-Didelphys

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Who has described the prognostic evaluation for PID?
questions.solution:
Boer-Meisel has described the prognostic evaluation for PID. It depends upon the following:

  1. Extent of adhesions
  2. Nature of adhesions such as flimsy or dense.
  3. Size of hydrosalpinx
  4. Macroscopic condition of hydrosalpinx.
  5. The thickness of the tubal wall.

Boer-Meisel system is specifically used for predicting pregnancy outcomes in patients treated for PID.

Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage.

  Stages of PID
Stage I Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - no adhesions
Stage II Acute salpingitis with peritonitis- purulent discharge
Stage III Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex
Stage IV Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
Stage V Tuberculous salpingitis

Westrom has reported that women with one previous attack of PID have a predisposition to another attack.

questions.text: A woman at 36 weeks of gestation was brought to the clinic by her concerned husband. He mentioned that over the last few weeks he noticed her chewing on cardboard pieces and ice cream sticks on multiple occasions. On examination, pallor was present and Hb was 8.6 g/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pica associated with moderate iron-deficiency anemia. Since the anemia was diagnosed late in pregnancy, the most appropriate treatment is parenteral iron therapy. Ferrous sucrose is a form of parenteral iron given as an IV infusion. 

If anemia is diagnosed:

  • In the first trimester - Oral iron therapy is preferred
  • In the second trimester - Oral iron therapy should be switched over to parenteral iron if Hb falls <8g/dl or if serum ferritin is <15ng/ml
  • In the third trimester - Parenteral iron therapy is preferred

Ferrous sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion. It is safe and does not require a test dose.

Other iron preparations include:

  • Oral preparations- Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, ferrous ascorbate 
  • IM preparations- Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose
  • IV preparations- Ferric carboxymaltose
  • Both IM and IV- Iron dextran.

questions.text: A menopausal woman presents with complaints of hot flushes. Which of the following neurotransmitters are responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine and serotonin are responsible for hot flushes in menopausal women.

A fall in the level of estrogen causes a reduction in hypothalamic endorphins. This causes a release of more norepinephrine and serotonin, which lower the set point in the thermoregulatory nucleus. As a result, the heat-loss mechanism is triggered by even subtle changes in core body temperature.

Risk factors for hot flushes:

  • Low estradiol levels
  • High BMI
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Surgical menopause has increased risk
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • History of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)
  • Depression.

questions.text:
Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
1) Abdominal A) Spiegelberg
2) Cervical B) Studdiford
3) Cornual C) Rubin
4) Ovarian
questions.solution:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
Abdominal Studdiford
Cervical Rubin
Ovarian  Spiegelberg

Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament.

Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface.

Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os.

questions.text: A young girl with McCune-Albright syndrome is noted to have precocious menstruation. This condition is defined as the occurrence of menstruation at____.
questions.solution:
Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years. 

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years.

McCune Albright syndrome is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (and precocious menstruation), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to recurrent fractures. The image given below shows cafe-au-lait spots.

questions.text: A young woman with an adnexal mass is diagnosed with dysgerminoma. Which of the following tumor markers are likely to be elevated in her?
questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase is the tumor marker in dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

It is seen in young women with an average incidence of 20 years of age. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors.

It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (PALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A P3L3 post-menopausal woman is diagnosed with type III genuine stress incontinence. Which of the following causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Type III genuine stress incontinence (GSI) is due to intrinsic sphincter deficiency.

Genuine stress incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine due to increased abdominal pressure in the absence of contraction of the detrusor muscle. It occurs when physical stress causes the bladder pressure to exceed the urethral pressure.

GSI is classified into three types based on the mechanism of incontinence:

Type of GSI Mechanism of incontinence
Type I Loss of posterior urethrovesical angle
Type II

Loss of posterior urethrovesical angle

Urethral hypermobility
Type III Intrinsic sphincter deficiency 

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) can further be graded into three different severities:

  • Grade 1 - Incontinence on severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, or jogging
  • Grade 2 - Incontinence on moderate stress such as walking fast or climbing stairs
  • Grade 3 - Incontinence on mild stress, such as on standing

questions.text: When does red degeneration of fibroids most commonly occur?
questions.solution:
Red/carneous degeneration occurs most commonly during the second trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Which the following are not the advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy?

choices.text: Trauma is avoided as no trocar is needed
Good view of the anterior surface of the ovary and genital organs

questions.solution:
Fertiloscopy helps in obtaining a good view of the posterior surface (and not the anterior surface) of the ovary and genital organs. This is an advantage of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy.

The other advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy are:

  • The Trendelenburg position is not needed. The procedure can be done in a lithotomy position
  • Trauma can be avoided as no trocar is needed
  • No CO2: Hydroperitoneum with saline
  • Peritoneal spill can be seen

Fertiloscopy is a new mini-invasive diagnostic technique that allows the visualization of the posterior pelvis. In this technique, an optical device is introduced into the pouch of Douglas, through the posterior vaginal fornix, under general/local anaesthesia.

It can also be used for small interventions, such as adhesiolysis, ovarian drilling, coagulation of endometriosis spots and to perform chromosalpingoscopy and salpingoscopy. With fertiloscopy, surgical intervention can be avoided and it is a good alternative to diagnostic laparoscopy.

The image given below is of a fertiloscope.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is performed using the instrument given in the image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a menstrual regulation syringe fitted with a Karman's cannula. Menstrual regulation involves aspiration of the contents of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with previously normal cycles.

Procedure of menstrual regulation:

  • The cervix is gently dilated using 4-5 mm-sized dilators.
  • A 5-6 mm Karman's cannula is then inserted and attached to a 50 mL syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

Contraindications of menstrual regulation:

  • Advanced pregnancy
  • Local pelvic inflammation

Manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) is done with an MVA syringe fitted with the Karman's cannula up to 12 weeks of gestation.

 

Suction and evacuation is done using a Karman's cannula attached to an automated suction apparatus.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia is started on prophylactic MgSO4 in view of signs of impending eclampsia. An hour later, examination reveals RR - 16 breaths/minute and absent patellar reflexes. What is her plasma concentration of MgSO4 most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there is no respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L.

The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome.

Signs of magnesium toxicity Plasma concentrations of magnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex 10–12
Respiratory depression 12-13 
Cardiac arrest >30

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which nerve is likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. 

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament. 

It is the most common obstetrical neuropathy after vaginal delivery, followed by femoral nerve involvement.

Note: The nerves most commonly injured during cesarean section are the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves.

questions.text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination, stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function

Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wall
  • Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis. 
  • Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment 
  • Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady presented to your clinics with lesions as shown in the below images. Which of the following is a false statement regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmented areas in the given image are acanthosis nigricans and this is associated with hyperinsulinemia. This skin condition is thought to be a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance.

Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in the intertriginous areas. It has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck, axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin. 

The pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans is linked to growth factor levels and insulin-mediated activation of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) on keratinocytes and increased growth factor levels.

Acanthosis nigricans is usually seen in people younger than 40 years of age and is associated with the following disorders:

  • Obesity
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Acromegaly
  • Polycystic ovary disease
  • Insulin-resistant diabetes
  • Cushing’s disease
  • Addison’s disease
  • Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas.

The treatment for acanthosis nigricans is directed towards the management of the underlying cause.
